blockTitle: Installs, Services and Maintains Generating, Distribution and Service Systems

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the minimum conductor size for a 100A single-phase residential service entrance?

options.B: #6 AWG copper

explanations.A: #8 AWG copper is rated for only 40A and is far too small for a 100A service entrance.
explanations.B: #6 AWG copper is rated for 65A and is insufficient for a 100A service entrance.
explanations.C: #4 AWG copper is rated for 100A and is the minimum size required for a 100A single-phase service entrance per CEC Table 2.
explanations.D: #2 AWG copper is rated for 115A and exceeds the minimum requirement, though it could be used for additional capacity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the standard height for mounting a meter socket on a residential building?

options.B: 1.5 to 1.8 meters (5 to 6 feet)

explanations.A: 1.2 to 1.5 meters is too low for convenient meter reading and may not meet utility requirements.
explanations.B: 1.5 to 1.8 meters is the standard mounting height for meter sockets, allowing convenient reading while meeting utility company specifications.
explanations.C: 1.8 to 2.0 meters is approaching the upper limit and may make meter reading difficult.
explanations.D: 2.0 to 2.5 meters is too high for convenient access and exceeds typical utility requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: When installing a service mast, what is the minimum height above the roof surface?

options.B: 1.5 meters (5 feet)

explanations.A: 1.0 meter does not provide adequate clearance above the roof for safety and code compliance.
explanations.B: 1.5 meters is insufficient clearance above the roof surface for service mast installations.
explanations.C: 2.0 meters is the minimum required clearance for service mast above a roof surface where the roof slope is less than 4:12, per CEC requirements.
explanations.D: 2.5 meters exceeds the minimum requirement but may be used for additional clearance or specific utility requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What type of weatherhead must be used for overhead service entrance conductors?

options.A: Any standard electrical box with a cover
options.B: A watertight weatherhead approved for service entrance use
options.C: A junction box with silicone sealant
options.D: No weatherhead is required if conductors are rated for wet locations

explanations.A: Standard electrical boxes do not provide adequate protection for overhead service entrance points.
explanations.B: A watertight weatherhead specifically approved for service entrance use must be installed to prevent water entry and protect the service entrance conductors.
explanations.C: Junction boxes with sealant do not meet code requirements for service entrance protection.
explanations.D: Even with wet-rated conductors, a proper weatherhead is required to prevent water intrusion and provide proper service entrance protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the maximum voltage drop allowed for a service entrance conductor?

explanations.A: The maximum recommended voltage drop for service entrance conductors is 1% to ensure adequate voltage is available for the entire electrical system.
explanations.B: 2% is the maximum recommended for branch circuits, not service conductors.
explanations.C: 3% is the combined maximum for feeder and branch circuits combined.
explanations.D: 5% total voltage drop is the absolute maximum for the entire system from service to final load but is not acceptable for service conductors alone.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: Where must the service disconnect be located in relation to the meter?

options.A: In a separate building from the meter
options.B: At the nearest accessible location after the meter, typically within or immediately adjacent to the building
options.C: At least 3 meters away from the meter

explanations.A: Service disconnects should be at the nearest accessible point after metering, not in separate buildings.
explanations.B: The service disconnect must be installed at the nearest accessible location after the meter, typically immediately after service entrance to allow rapid disconnection in emergencies.
explanations.C: There is no requirement for minimum distance; the disconnect should be as close as practical after the meter.
explanations.D: Service disconnects can be located wherever accessible and appropriate, not exclusively in basements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is required when service entrance conductors pass through a wall or foundation?

options.A: Direct burial of conductors through the opening
options.B: A watertight bushing or sleeve to protect conductors and prevent water entry

explanations.A: Direct burial through wall openings without protection can damage conductor insulation.
explanations.B: Conductors passing through walls or foundations require watertight bushings or sleeves to prevent abrasion damage and water infiltration into the building.
explanations.C: Electrical tape provides inadequate protection against mechanical damage and water entry.
explanations.D: Protection is mandatory when conductors pass through building envelopes to prevent damage and water entry.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What color coding is required for the grounded neutral conductor in a single-phase service?

options.B: Red

explanations.A: Green or bare conductors are for equipment grounding, not the grounded neutral.
explanations.B: Red is typically used for ungrounded phase conductors, not neutral.
explanations.C: The grounded neutral conductor must be white or grey throughout the service entrance to clearly identify it per CEC requirements.
explanations.D: Black is used for ungrounded phase conductors, not the neutral.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required for overhead service drop conductors above a residential driveway?

options.B: 3.5 meters (11.5 feet)

explanations.A: 3.0 meters is insufficient clearance over driveways where vehicles pass.
explanations.B: 3.5 meters does not meet minimum clearance requirements for vehicular areas.
explanations.C: 4.0 meters is the minimum clearance required for service drop conductors above residential driveways to allow safe passage of vehicles.
explanations.D: 5.0 meters exceeds the minimum requirement and is typically required over public roads, not residential driveways.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: When must a meter main combination panel be used instead of separate meter and panel?

options.B: When the service is over 200A
options.C: When a single device combining metering and main disconnect is desired for economy and space savings

explanations.A: Meter main combinations are optional, not mandatory for all installations.
explanations.B: Meter main combinations are available in various amperage ratings and are not limited by service size.
explanations.C: Meter main combinations are used when integrating metering and main disconnect in one enclosure is advantageous for cost, space, or installation convenience.
explanations.D: Meter main combinations are fully code-compliant when properly installed and listed.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the minimum conductor size for a 200A three-phase service entrance using copper conductors?

options.B: #1 AWG

explanations.A: #2 AWG copper is rated for 115A and is far too small for 200A service.
explanations.B: #1 AWG copper is rated for 130A and is insufficient for 200A service.
explanations.C: #1/0 AWG copper is rated for 150A and still does not meet 200A requirements.
explanations.D: #3/0 AWG copper is rated for 200A and is the minimum size required for a 200A three-phase service entrance per CEC ampacity tables.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: In a 120/208V three-phase four-wire wye service, what voltage exists between any phase conductor and neutral?

explanations.A: In a 120/208V wye system, the phase-to-neutral voltage is 120V, providing standard voltage for lighting and receptacle loads.
explanations.B: 208V is the phase-to-phase voltage in this system, not phase-to-neutral.
explanations.C: 240V is not present in a 120/208V system; it would be found in delta or split-phase systems.
explanations.D: 347V is the phase-to-neutral voltage in a 600V wye system, not a 120/208V system.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What type of meter socket is required for a three-phase four-wire service?

options.B: Single-phase three-wire meter socket
options.D: Any meter socket with surge protection

explanations.A: Single-phase two-wire meter sockets cannot accommodate three-phase services.
explanations.B: Single-phase three-wire meter sockets are designed for residential split-phase service, not three-phase.
explanations.C: Three-phase four-wire services require a four-jaw meter socket to accommodate three phase conductors and one neutral conductor.
explanations.D: Surge protection features do not determine socket type; jaw configuration for phase conductors is the critical factor.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the standard phase rotation sequence for three-phase systems in North America?

options.B: A-B-C or 1-2-3
options.D: Phase rotation is random and not standardized

explanations.A: A-C-B or reverse rotation is incorrect and can cause motor rotation problems.
explanations.B: The standard phase rotation in North America is A-B-C (or 1-2-3), which determines the direction three-phase motors will rotate.
explanations.C: C-B-A is reverse rotation and not the standard sequence.
explanations.D: Phase rotation is standardized to ensure proper equipment operation, particularly motor rotation direction.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: When installing CT (current transformer) metering for a large three-phase service, where should the CTs be located?

options.A: On the load side of the main breaker
options.B: On the line side of the main breaker, one CT on each phase conductor
options.D: CT metering is not used for three-phase services

explanations.A: CTs must be on the line side (utility side) of the main breaker to accurately measure all power supplied by the utility.
explanations.B: CTs are installed on the line side of the main disconnect, with one CT on each phase conductor to accurately measure total power consumption for billing.
explanations.C: CTs on only the neutral conductor cannot measure three-phase power; they must be on all phase conductors.
explanations.D: CT metering is commonly used for three-phase services exceeding 200A where direct metering would require impractically large meter equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the color coding standard for phase conductors in a three-phase system?

options.B: Black, Red, Blue

explanations.A: White is reserved for neutral conductors, not phase conductors.
explanations.B: The standard color coding in Canada for three-phase conductors is Black (Phase A), Red (Phase B), and Blue (Phase C).
explanations.C: Brown, Orange, Yellow is the IEC standard used in some countries but not the Canadian standard.
explanations.D: Green is reserved for grounding conductors and should never be used for phase conductors.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: In a 347/600V three-phase wye service, what is the phase-to-phase voltage?

explanations.A: 347V is the phase-to-neutral voltage, not phase-to-phase.
explanations.B: 480V is not present in a 347/600V system; it's found in 277/480V systems.
explanations.C: 600V is the phase-to-phase voltage in a 347/600V wye system, commonly used in larger commercial and industrial installations.
explanations.D: 750V exceeds the voltages present in this system.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What must be verified before energizing a new three-phase service?

options.A: Only that the main breaker is off
options.B: Correct phase rotation, proper grounding, and phase balance
options.C: That all lights are turned off

explanations.A: Breaker position alone is insufficient; multiple technical parameters must be verified.
explanations.B: Before energization, phase rotation must be correct for proper motor operation, grounding must be verified, and phase balance should be checked to ensure proper installation.
explanations.C: Load status is less critical than electrical parameters during initial energization testing.
explanations.D: While weather may affect scheduling, electrical parameters are the critical verification items.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the advantage of a three-phase delta service over a wye service?

options.A: Delta systems provide neutral conductors for 120V loads
options.B: Delta systems can provide higher phase-to-phase voltage for the same phase conductor size
options.C: Delta systems are always more efficient

explanations.A: Standard delta systems do not provide a neutral; wye systems provide neutrals for single-phase loads.
explanations.B: Delta configurations can deliver higher phase-to-phase voltage without a neutral, making them suitable for industrial motor loads and power distribution.
explanations.C: Efficiency depends on the specific application and load, not solely on delta vs. wye configuration.
explanations.D: Both delta and wye three-phase systems typically require three or four conductors depending on configuration.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: When installing three-phase service entrance conductors, how should they be arranged in conduit?

options.A: All phase conductors together, neutral separate
options.B: Each phase in a separate conduit
options.C: All conductors (phases, neutral, and ground) bundled together in the same conduit to minimize inductance

explanations.A: Separating neutral from phase conductors can create inductive heating issues in ferrous conduits.
explanations.B: Separating phases into individual conduits creates high inductance and heating in steel conduit.
explanations.C: All current-carrying conductors including phases, neutral, and grounding must be in the same conduit to ensure magnetic fields cancel and prevent inductive heating.
explanations.D: Conductor arrangement is critical for preventing inductive heating and must follow specific requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What test should be performed when servicing a meter socket?

options.B: Voltage measurement, tightness of connections, and condition of jaws
options.D: No testing is required for meter sockets

explanations.A: Visual inspection alone is insufficient; electrical testing and mechanical verification are essential.
explanations.B: Meter socket servicing includes voltage verification, checking jaw tightness and condition for proper meter contact, and inspecting for corrosion or damage.
explanations.C: Power consumption analysis is done through meter readings, not during socket servicing.
explanations.D: Regular testing is essential to ensure safe and accurate metering.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the most common cause of service entrance conductor failure?

options.B: Loose connections causing overheating

explanations.A: While lightning can damage services, loose connections are far more common.
explanations.B: Loose connections create high resistance, leading to heat generation, insulation degradation, and eventual conductor failure, making this the most common service failure mode.
explanations.C: UV degradation affects outdoor insulation over time but is less common than connection issues.
explanations.D: Animal damage occurs but is less frequent than thermal failure from poor connections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: When should service entrance conductors be replaced during service work?

options.B: When insulation shows cracking, brittleness, or conductor corrosion is evident

explanations.A: Age alone does not determine replacement; condition assessment is key.
explanations.B: Service conductors should be replaced when insulation deteriorates (cracking, brittleness), conductors show corrosion, or any damage compromises safety or current-carrying capacity.
explanations.C: Waiting for complete failure is dangerous; deteriorated conductors should be replaced before failure.
explanations.D: Service conductors eventually degrade and require replacement when condition warrants.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What should be checked when servicing a weatherhead?

options.A: Only the color of the paint
options.B: Seal integrity, physical damage, and conductor entry condition

explanations.A: Paint condition is cosmetic; functional integrity is what matters.
explanations.B: Weatherhead servicing includes checking the watertight seal, inspecting for cracks or physical damage, and ensuring conductor entry points maintain weather protection.
explanations.C: Manufacturing date is less relevant than current condition.
explanations.D: Weight is not a servicing concern; weatherproofing and physical integrity are critical.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the proper procedure for removing a meter for service work?

options.A: Pull the meter while the service is energized
options.B: Cut the service conductors and then remove the meter
options.C: Coordinate with the utility company for proper disconnection procedures, typically requiring utility personnel to pull the meter
options.D: Remove the meter only during lightning storms

explanations.A: Pulling energized meters creates extreme arc flash hazard and is prohibited.
explanations.B: Cutting service conductors is dangerous and damages the installation.
explanations.C: Meter removal requires coordination with the utility company, as they typically own the meter and have specific procedures for disconnection to ensure safety and prevent tampering.
explanations.D: Weather conditions do not determine meter removal procedures; utility coordination does.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What tool is essential for verifying correct phase rotation during three-phase service work?

options.B: Phase rotation tester (phase sequence indicator)

explanations.A: Multimeters measure voltage but cannot determine phase rotation sequence.
explanations.B: Phase rotation testers specifically indicate whether phases are in correct A-B-C sequence or reversed, which is critical for proper motor operation.
explanations.C: Clamp ammeters measure current but cannot determine phase sequence.
explanations.D: Megohmmeters test insulation resistance but cannot verify phase rotation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: When servicing a three-phase service, what indicates unbalanced loading?

options.A: All phases showing identical current readings
options.B: Significant current differences between phases (typically more than 10% deviation)

explanations.A: Identical current readings indicate balanced loading, not unbalanced.
explanations.B: Unbalanced loading is indicated by significant current differences between phases, which can cause overheating, reduced efficiency, and equipment problems.
explanations.C: Equal voltage indicates proper supply, not balanced loading.
explanations.D: Meter accuracy is unrelated to load balance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the consequence of reversed phase rotation in a three-phase service?

options.B: Motors will rotate in the wrong direction, potentially damaging equipment
options.D: The service will not energize at all

explanations.A: Reversed rotation significantly affects motor operation and equipment function.
explanations.B: Reversed phase rotation causes three-phase motors to rotate backwards, which can damage pumps, fans, compressors, and other equipment designed for specific rotation.
explanations.C: Phase rotation does not affect voltage magnitude.
explanations.D: The service will energize, but equipment will operate incorrectly.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: When servicing CT metering equipment, what safety precaution is critical?

options.A: CTs can be opened while energized without concern
options.B: CT secondary circuits must never be open-circuited while the primary is energized due to high voltage generation

explanations.A: Opening CT secondaries while energized is extremely dangerous and can generate lethal voltages.
explanations.B: Opening a CT secondary while the primary is energized can generate extremely high voltages (thousands of volts) that can destroy the CT and create serious shock hazards.
explanations.C: CTs require specific safety procedures to prevent dangerous voltage generation.
explanations.D: CT polarity is critical for accurate power measurement and must be maintained.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What measurement indicates potential neutral conductor problems in a three-phase four-wire system?

options.B: Excessive current on the neutral conductor or unbalanced phase-to-neutral voltages

explanations.A: Balanced phase voltages indicate proper neutral connection.
explanations.B: Excessive neutral current or voltage imbalance between phases indicates neutral conductor problems such as loose connections, undersized neutral, or high resistance.
explanations.C: Equal phase currents indicate balanced loading, not neutral problems.
explanations.D: Phase rotation is unrelated to neutral conductor condition.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the purpose of the grounding electrode conductor in a service entrance?

options.B: To provide a path to earth for fault currents and lightning protection
options.C: To serve as an emergency neutral

explanations.A: Grounding electrode conductors should carry no current during normal operation.
explanations.B: The grounding electrode conductor connects the service neutral and equipment to earth, providing a reference point and path for lightning and fault currents to dissipate safely.
explanations.C: The grounding conductor is not designed to serve as a current-carrying neutral.
explanations.D: Grounding does not affect service voltage levels.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the minimum burial depth for underground service lateral conductors in rigid conduit under a driveway?

options.B: 450 mm (18 inches)

explanations.A: 300 mm is insufficient depth under vehicular traffic areas.
explanations.B: 450 mm does not meet minimum requirements for driveways.
explanations.C: 600 mm (24 inches) is the minimum burial depth for underground service conductors in rigid conduit under driveways to protect against vehicular loads.
explanations.D: 900 mm exceeds the minimum requirement, though deeper burial provides additional protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: In a high-leg delta service, which conductor has a higher voltage to ground?

options.B: The center-tapped phase creating the high leg
options.D: All phases have equal voltage to ground

explanations.A: Phase A typically has the same voltage to ground as Phase C.
explanations.B: The high leg (typically Phase B) has approximately 208V to ground in a 120/240V delta system, compared to 120V for the other phases, requiring orange identification.
explanations.C: The neutral is at ground potential and has zero voltage to ground.
explanations.D: High-leg delta systems specifically have one phase with higher voltage to ground.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What color must the high leg conductor be identified with in a delta service?

options.B: Orange

explanations.A: Red is used for standard phase conductors, not specifically for the high leg.
explanations.B: The high leg conductor must be identified with orange color per CEC requirements to warn that it has higher voltage to ground than other phases.
explanations.C: Yellow is not the required color for high leg identification in Canadian standards.
explanations.D: Purple is not used for high leg identification.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the recommended torque specification for service entrance conductor terminations?

options.B: As tight as possible with any tool
options.C: According to manufacturer specifications using a calibrated torque tool
options.D: Torque specifications don't matter for service conductors

explanations.A: Hand-tight may not provide adequate connection pressure and can lead to loose connections.
explanations.B: Over-tightening can damage terminals and conductors.
explanations.C: Service terminations must be tightened to manufacturer specifications using calibrated torque tools to ensure proper contact pressure without damage.
explanations.D: Proper torque is critical for safe, reliable service connections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.03 Services single-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What indicates a corroded service entrance connection during inspection?

options.B: Green or white powdery deposits, discoloration, or pitting on conductors and terminals

explanations.A: Shiny, clean surfaces indicate good condition without corrosion.
explanations.B: Corrosion appears as green (copper oxide) or white deposits, discoloration, and surface pitting, indicating moisture intrusion and oxidation that increases resistance.
explanations.C: Smooth surfaces indicate no corrosion; corrosion creates rough, degraded surfaces.
explanations.D: Temperature alone doesn't indicate corrosion, though corroded connections may run hot.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the purpose of a phase loss monitor in a three-phase service?

options.B: To detect loss of one or more phases and protect equipment from single-phase operation

explanations.A: Power consumption monitoring uses different equipment like power meters.
explanations.B: Phase loss monitors detect when one or more phases are lost and disconnect equipment to prevent damage from single-phasing, which can destroy motors.
explanations.C: Load balancing requires different equipment and control strategies.
explanations.D: Power factor correction uses capacitor banks, not phase loss monitors.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.04 Services three-phase systems and metering equipment
questions.question: When servicing a three-phase service, what voltage test should be performed?

options.B: Test all phase-to-phase and phase-to-neutral voltages to verify balance and proper connection

explanations.A: Testing only one phase does not reveal balance problems or incorrect connections.
explanations.B: Complete voltage testing includes all phase-to-phase and phase-to-neutral measurements to verify balanced supply, correct connections, and proper system voltage.
explanations.C: Neutral-to-ground voltage alone does not verify phase voltages or balance.
explanations.D: Voltage testing is essential to verify proper service operation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.01 Installs single-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the maximum distance between supports for service entrance cable (SEU/SER)?

options.B: 1.0 meter

explanations.A: 0.5 meters is overly conservative and not required by code.
explanations.B: Service entrance cable must be supported at intervals not exceeding 1.0 meter and within 300 mm of terminations to prevent sagging and cable stress.
explanations.C: 1.5 meters exceeds code requirements and could result in excessive sag.
explanations.D: All service cables require proper support to maintain installation integrity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.subtask: B-7.02 Installs three-phase consumer/supply services and metering equipment
questions.question: What is the main advantage of using a wye-configured three-phase service in commercial buildings?

options.A: Wye systems cannot provide neutral connections
options.B: Wye systems provide a neutral point for single-phase loads and lighting while delivering three-phase power
options.C: Wye systems are less expensive than delta

explanations.A: Wye systems specifically provide neutral connections; this is one of their key advantages.
explanations.B: Wye configurations provide a neutral point allowing connection of 120V or 277V single-phase loads for lighting and receptacles while simultaneously providing three-phase power for motors and equipment.
explanations.C: Cost differences depend on specific requirements, not inherent configuration advantages.
explanations.D: Wye systems have significant advantages for mixed single and three-phase load applications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the maximum overcurrent protection allowed for #14 AWG copper conductors?

explanations.A: 10A provides extra protection but is not the maximum allowed for #14 AWG.
explanations.B: 15A is the maximum overcurrent protection permitted for #14 AWG copper conductors per CEC requirements to prevent conductor overheating.
explanations.C: 20A exceeds the safe current-carrying capacity of #14 AWG and would allow dangerous overheating.
explanations.D: 30A is far too large for #14 AWG and would create serious fire hazards.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What type of circuit breaker provides inverse time-current characteristics?

options.B: Thermal-magnetic circuit breaker

explanations.A: Instantaneous trip breakers respond immediately to overcurrent without time delay.
explanations.B: Thermal-magnetic breakers have inverse time-current characteristics, where higher overcurrents cause faster tripping, allowing temporary overloads while protecting against sustained overcurrent.
explanations.C: While electronic breakers can provide this characteristic, thermal-magnetic breakers inherently provide it.
explanations.D: Ground fault function is separate from inverse time-current overcurrent protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the maximum number of circuit breaker handle ties allowed in a panel to create a multi-pole breaker?

options.B: Three poles maximum
options.C: Handle ties are not code-compliant; only factory-assembled multi-pole breakers are permitted

explanations.A: Even two-pole handle ties are not code-compliant as a substitute for proper multi-pole breakers.
explanations.B: Handle ties regardless of number do not meet code requirements.
explanations.C: Handle ties (breaker ties) are not acceptable for creating multi-pole breakers; only factory-assembled multi-pole breakers with common trip mechanisms are code-compliant.
explanations.D: There is no provision for handle ties to create multi-pole protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the interrupting rating of a circuit breaker?

options.A: The normal operating current of the breaker
options.B: The maximum fault current the breaker can safely interrupt without damage
options.C: The voltage rating of the breaker
options.D: The physical size of the breaker

explanations.A: Normal operating current is the continuous current rating, not interrupting rating.
explanations.B: Interrupting rating (AIC - Amperes Interrupting Capacity) is the maximum fault current the breaker can safely interrupt without destruction, typically 10,000A or 22,000A for residential applications.
explanations.C: Voltage rating is separate from interrupting capacity.
explanations.D: Physical size does not define interrupting rating, though higher ratings may require larger housings.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: When are fuses preferred over circuit breakers in electrical installations?

options.A: Fuses are never preferred; breakers are always better
options.B: In applications requiring precise current limitation or extremely high interrupting ratings

explanations.A: Fuses have specific advantages in certain applications.
explanations.B: Current-limiting fuses provide superior fault current limitation and are available with very high interrupting ratings (200,000A+), making them preferable for industrial applications and service entrances.
explanations.C: Circuit breakers are more common in residential applications due to convenience.
explanations.D: Frequent resetting favors breakers; fuses must be replaced after operation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is a Class J fuse primarily used for?

options.B: Current-limiting protection in industrial applications with high available fault current

explanations.A: Residential lighting typically uses standard plug fuses or circuit breakers, not Class J fuses.
explanations.B: Class J fuses are current-limiting fuses designed for industrial applications, providing fast response to high fault currents and protection for equipment and conductors.
explanations.C: Class J fuses are rated for AC applications, not specifically for DC circuits.
explanations.D: Temporary power typically uses circuit breakers for convenience.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What does the term 'selective coordination' mean in overcurrent protection?

options.B: Sizing protection devices so only the breaker closest to the fault trips, leaving upstream devices closed
options.C: Installing all breakers of the same brand
options.D: Using only fuses instead of breakers

explanations.A: Cost is not a factor in selective coordination; protection performance is key.
explanations.B: Selective coordination ensures that when a fault occurs, only the overcurrent device immediately upstream of the fault opens, maintaining power to unaffected circuits and minimizing disruption.
explanations.C: Brand consistency does not ensure selective coordination; proper sizing and characteristics do.
explanations.D: Selective coordination can be achieved with breakers, fuses, or combinations of both.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the purpose of a circuit breaker's thermal element?

options.B: To provide time-delay protection against sustained overloads by responding to heat
options.C: To provide instantaneous short circuit protection

explanations.A: Ground fault detection requires separate GFCI mechanisms, not thermal elements.
explanations.B: The thermal element (bimetallic strip) bends when heated by overcurrent, providing time-delayed response to sustained overloads while allowing temporary inrush currents.
explanations.C: Instantaneous protection is provided by the magnetic element, not the thermal element.
explanations.D: Power measurement requires separate metering equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: When must a two-pole breaker be used instead of two single-pole breakers?

options.A: Never; single-pole breakers are always acceptable
options.B: For 240V loads or multi-wire branch circuits requiring simultaneous disconnection of both ungrounded conductors
options.D: Only when the panel is full

explanations.A: Two-pole breakers are required in specific situations for safety.
explanations.B: Two-pole breakers are required for 240V loads, multi-wire branch circuits, and any application where both ungrounded conductors must disconnect simultaneously for safety.
explanations.C: Two-pole breaker requirements apply to both residential and commercial installations.
explanations.D: Panel capacity does not determine when two-pole breakers are required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the 80% rule for continuous loads in relation to overcurrent protection?

options.A: Breakers should be loaded to 80% of panel capacity
options.B: Continuous loads (operating for 3 hours or more) should not exceed 80% of the OCPD rating unless the device is rated for 100% continuous operation
options.C: 80% of breakers must be identical brands

explanations.A: The 80% rule applies to individual breaker ratings, not overall panel capacity.
explanations.B: Continuous loads must not exceed 80% of the overcurrent device rating unless the device is specifically rated for 100% continuous duty, preventing overheating from sustained current.
explanations.C: Breaker brand consistency is unrelated to the continuous load rule.
explanations.D: The 80% rule concerns current and overcurrent protection, not voltage levels.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: At what ground fault current level does a standard GFCI trip?

options.B: 5 mA

explanations.A: 1 mA would cause nuisance tripping from normal leakage currents.
explanations.B: Standard GFCIs are designed to trip at 5 mA (1 mA), which is below the threshold of sustained ventricular fibrillation, providing effective shock protection.
explanations.C: 30 mA is the trip level for equipment protection GFCIs, which is too high for personnel protection.
explanations.D: 100 mA is far too high and could allow lethal shock; this level is not used for personnel protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: Where are GFCI receptacles required in residential construction?

options.B: In bathrooms, kitchen countertop receptacles, outdoors, garages, unfinished basements, and within 1.5m of sinks

explanations.A: GFCI requirements extend far beyond just kitchens.
explanations.B: CEC requires GFCI protection in all areas where water contact is likely: bathrooms, kitchen countertops, outdoors, garages, unfinished basements, and within 1.5 meters of sinks.
explanations.C: GFCI protection is mandatory in specified locations, not optional.
explanations.D: GFCI requirements include many interior locations, not just outdoor areas.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: What is the primary function of an Arc Fault Circuit Interrupter (AFCI)?

options.B: To detect and interrupt dangerous arc faults that could cause fires

explanations.A: Ground fault protection is provided by GFCIs, not AFCIs.
explanations.B: AFCIs detect the characteristic signatures of dangerous arcing (parallel or series arcs) and interrupt the circuit to prevent electrical fires caused by damaged wiring or connections.
explanations.C: Surge protection is provided by SPDs, not AFCIs.
explanations.D: Power measurement requires metering equipment, not AFCIs.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: In what areas are AFCI breakers required for residential branch circuits?

options.B: All 125V, 15A and 20A branch circuits in dwelling units including bedrooms, living areas, hallways, closets, and similar spaces
options.D: AFCIs are not required by code

explanations.A: AFCI requirements extend beyond bedrooms in current code editions.
explanations.B: Modern CEC requirements mandate AFCI protection for all 125V, 15A and 20A branch circuits in dwelling units, covering bedrooms, living rooms, hallways, closets, and similar areas to prevent electrical fires.
explanations.C: AFCI requirements primarily apply to residential dwelling units, though some commercial applications may benefit.
explanations.D: AFCI protection is required by code in specified residential locations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: What is the difference between a Type 1 and Type 2 surge protective device (SPD)?

options.B: Type 1 is installed on the line side of the main OCPD; Type 2 is installed on the load side
options.C: Type 2 provides better protection than Type 1

explanations.A: Cost is not the defining difference between Type 1 and Type 2 SPDs.
explanations.B: Type 1 SPDs can be installed on the line side (utility side) of the service disconnect and handle direct lightning strikes, while Type 2 SPDs are installed on the load side and provide protection against induced surges.
explanations.C: Type 1 actually provides more robust protection than Type 2; Type 2 is for secondary protection.
explanations.D: Significant differences exist in installation location, protection level, and surge current handling.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: How should a GFCI be tested after installation?

options.B: Press the test button to verify it trips, then reset; test monthly during use
options.D: Only test if it fails to operate

explanations.A: Visual inspection cannot verify GFCI electrical function; functional testing is required.
explanations.B: GFCIs must be tested using the test button after installation and monthly thereafter to ensure proper operation; the device should trip when tested and reset properly.
explanations.C: Regular testing is essential to verify continued GFCI protection.
explanations.D: Testing should be proactive, not reactive to failures.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: What is a combination AFCI/GFCI breaker?

options.A: A device that provides both arc fault and ground fault protection in one unit
options.B: Two separate breakers tied together
options.C: A device that only protects against arc faults
options.D: A standard circuit breaker with a different label

explanations.A: Combination AFCI/GFCI breakers integrate both arc fault detection and ground fault protection in one device, providing comprehensive protection against fires and shock hazards.
explanations.B: Combination devices are single integrated units, not two separate devices.
explanations.C: Combination devices provide both types of protection, not just arc fault protection.
explanations.D: Combination devices have specific internal circuitry for both protection types, not just labeling.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: Where should whole-house surge protection be installed?

options.A: At the last receptacle in each circuit
options.B: At the service entrance panel or meter base
options.D: Surge protection should not be installed at service entrance

explanations.A: Individual receptacle SPDs provide point-of-use protection but whole-house protection goes at the service.
explanations.B: Whole-house surge protection should be installed at the service entrance panel or meter base to protect the entire electrical system from external surges before they enter the building wiring.
explanations.C: Room-by-room installation is point-of-use protection, not whole-house protection.
explanations.D: Service entrance is the ideal location for primary surge protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: What voltage rating is required for surge protective devices in a 120/240V residential service?

options.B: 240V minimum
options.D: Voltage rating doesn't matter for SPDs

explanations.A: 120V rating is insufficient for protecting a 120/240V system.
explanations.B: SPDs must be rated for at least the maximum system voltage (240V) to properly protect all conductors in a residential split-phase service.
explanations.C: 150V would be inadequate for the 240V phase-to-phase voltage.
explanations.D: Proper voltage rating is essential for SPD effectiveness and safety.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: What is the purpose of the neutral wire connection in a GFCI receptacle?

options.A: To provide a return path for normal current and allow the GFCI to compare current flow for ground fault detection
options.B: The neutral is not used in GFCIs

explanations.A: The GFCI monitors current flow on both hot and neutral conductors; if they differ by more than 5mA (indicating current leaking to ground), the GFCI trips, requiring proper neutral connection.
explanations.B: Neutral connection is essential for GFCI operation.
explanations.C: Grounding uses the equipment ground conductor, not the neutral.
explanations.D: Neutral connection does not affect receptacle capacity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the proper procedure for testing a circuit breaker during service?

options.A: Repeatedly flip the breaker on and off rapidly
options.B: Manually operate the breaker, verify proper mechanical action, and test trip function under controlled conditions
options.C: Apply maximum voltage to force a trip

explanations.A: Rapid repeated operation can damage breaker mechanisms and does not properly test function.
explanations.B: Proper breaker testing includes manual operation to verify smooth action, visual inspection for damage, and controlled testing of trip function using appropriate test equipment.
explanations.C: Forcing trips with excessive voltage can damage breakers and is not a proper test procedure.
explanations.D: Regular testing is important to verify continued breaker functionality.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What indicates that a circuit breaker should be replaced during service?

options.A: The breaker is more than 1 year old
options.B: Signs of overheating, physical damage, failure to trip at rated current, or failure to reset properly
options.C: The breaker has been tripped once

explanations.A: Age alone does not determine replacement; condition and performance are key.
explanations.B: Breakers should be replaced when showing heat damage, physical damage, improper trip characteristics, or mechanical problems, as these indicate compromised protection.
explanations.C: Single trips from overload or fault are normal operation; repeated nuisance trips may indicate problems.
explanations.D: Breakers do wear out and fail over time and must be replaced when defective.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: When servicing GFCI devices, what indicates they need replacement?

options.A: Device age over 10-15 years, failure to trip when test button is pressed, or frequent nuisance tripping
options.B: GFCIs never need replacement
options.C: Only if they are physically broken

explanations.A: GFCIs should be replaced if they fail the test button, trip without cause, or are over 10-15 years old as their internal electronics degrade over time.
explanations.B: GFCIs do degrade and must be replaced to maintain protection.
explanations.C: Functional failure is as important as physical damage; non-functional GFCIs should be replaced even if undamaged.
explanations.D: Color change is not a functional indicator; electrical performance determines replacement needs.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: How should fuses be tested during service work?

options.B: Remove fuse and test continuity with a multimeter to verify the fuse element is intact
options.C: Tap the fuse with a hammer

explanations.A: Visual inspection may not reveal all fuse failures; electrical testing is more reliable.
explanations.B: After de-energizing the circuit, fuses should be removed and tested with a multimeter for continuity; an open circuit indicates a blown fuse requiring replacement.
explanations.C: Physical impact testing is inappropriate and could damage good fuses.
explanations.D: Fuses can and should be tested to verify integrity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the danger of using an oversized fuse during service work?

options.A: The fuse will blow more frequently
options.B: Oversized fuses may not protect conductors and equipment from overheating, creating fire hazards
options.D: There is no danger; any fuse size works

explanations.A: Oversized fuses blow less frequently, which is the problemthey don't provide adequate protection.
explanations.B: Fuses must be sized to protect the conductors and equipment they serve; oversized fuses allow damaging overcurrent that can cause fires or equipment destruction.
explanations.C: Cost is not the safety concern with oversized fuses.
explanations.D: Proper fuse sizing is critical for adequate circuit protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What maintenance is required for surge protective devices?

options.B: Regular inspection of indicator lights or status displays, and replacement when indicators show failure

explanations.A: SPDs require periodic inspection to verify continued protection.
explanations.B: SPDs should be inspected regularly for status indicator lights; many SPDs have indicators showing when MOV components have degraded and the device needs replacement.
explanations.C: Water cleaning is inappropriate and dangerous for electrical devices.
explanations.D: Daily testing is excessive; visual status checks at reasonable intervals are appropriate.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: When servicing a panel, what indicates overheating at breaker connections?

options.A: Discoloration, melted insulation, burnt smells, or excessive heat at terminations
options.B: The breaker is cold to touch
options.C: The breaker is a bright color
options.D: There are no indicators of overheating

explanations.A: Overheating signs include discolored or melted conductor insulation, burnt odors, discolored breakers or bus bars, and elevated temperature at connectionsall requiring immediate correction.
explanations.B: Cool temperature indicates normal operation, not overheating.
explanations.C: Color brightness is not an indicator of thermal problems.
explanations.D: Clear indicators exist for overheating and must be recognized during service.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the proper method for replacing a circuit breaker in an energized panel?

options.A: Never replace breakers in energized panels; de-energize the panel first
options.B: Quickly swap breakers while panel is energized

explanations.A: Panels must be de-energized before breaker replacement to prevent arc flash and electrocution hazards; only qualified personnel with appropriate training may work on energized equipment when absolutely necessary.
explanations.B: Working on energized panels creates extreme arc flash and shock hazards.
explanations.C: Rubber gloves alone provide inadequate protection for energized panel work.
explanations.D: Weather conditions are irrelevant; proper de-energization procedures must be followed.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.question: What is the minimum requirement for overcurrent protection in a multi-wire branch circuit?

options.A: Single-pole breaker on one ungrounded conductor only
options.B: Simultaneous disconnection of all ungrounded conductors using a multi-pole breaker or handle-tied breakers
options.C: Separate breakers with no connection requirement

explanations.A: Protecting only one conductor of a multi-wire circuit creates hazards.
explanations.B: Multi-wire branch circuits require simultaneous disconnection of all ungrounded conductors to prevent dangerous voltage on equipment when one breaker is off, though handle ties are no longer generally acceptable.
explanations.C: Independent breakers without simultaneous disconnection create safety hazards in multi-wire circuits.
explanations.D: All circuits require proper overcurrent protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains protection devices
questions.subtask: B-8.02 Installs GFCI, AFCI and surge protection devices
questions.question: Can GFCI and AFCI protection be provided at the panel using breakers instead of receptacles?

options.A: No, only receptacle-type devices are code-compliant
options.B: Yes, GFCI and AFCI breakers installed in the panel provide protection for entire circuits
options.C: Only GFCI can be at the panel, not AFCI
options.D: Neither type can be installed at the panel

explanations.A: Both receptacle and breaker types are code-compliant for GFCI and AFCI protection.
explanations.B: GFCI and AFCI breakers installed at the panel protect entire branch circuits downstream, offering protection at all points on the circuit unlike receptacle devices.
explanations.C: Both GFCI and AFCI are available as circuit breakers for panel installation.
explanations.D: Panel-mounted breakers are a common and effective method for providing both types of protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the purpose of a distribution panel (subpanel)?

options.A: To replace the main service panel
options.B: To distribute power from the main panel or another source to branch circuits in a specific area
options.C: To increase voltage in the building

explanations.A: Distribution panels supplement main panels but do not replace them.
explanations.B: Distribution panels receive power from main panels or other sources and distribute it to branch circuits, allowing circuit concentration in specific building areas.
explanations.C: Distribution panels distribute power at supplied voltage; they do not increase voltage.
explanations.D: Panels distribute power; they do not store energy.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is required for bonding and grounding in a distribution panel fed from a main panel?

options.A: Bond neutral and ground together at the subpanel
options.B: Isolate neutral and ground; run separate neutral and grounding conductors from the main panel
options.C: No grounding is required at subpanels
options.D: Use the conduit as the only ground path

explanations.A: Bonding neutral and ground at subpanels creates dangerous parallel ground paths.
explanations.B: In subpanels, neutral and ground must be isolated (separate buses) with separate neutral and equipment grounding conductors run from the main panel to prevent objectionable current on grounding paths.
explanations.C: Proper grounding is essential at all panels including subpanels.
explanations.D: Conduit may supplement but cannot be the sole equipment grounding path; a dedicated grounding conductor is required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the minimum wire bending space required at panel terminals per CEC?

options.B: Bending space must meet minimum dimensions based on conductor size to prevent insulation damage

explanations.A: CEC specifies minimum bending space to protect conductors.
explanations.B: CEC Table 12 specifies minimum wire bending space at terminals based on conductor size, ensuring adequate room to bend conductors without damaging insulation or exceeding minimum bend radius.
explanations.C: Insufficient bending space can damage conductor insulation and create safety hazards.
explanations.D: Required space varies with conductor size; a single 1-inch minimum does not apply to all sizes.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the maximum number of circuits (overcurrent devices) allowed in a residential panelboard?

options.B: 42 circuits
options.C: There is no maximum specified in current code; it depends on panel design

explanations.A: 30 circuits is common for smaller panels but not the maximum allowed.
explanations.B: Current CEC limits residential panelboards to 42 overcurrent device poles maximum (2-pole breakers count as 2 poles).
explanations.C: CEC does specify a maximum of 42 poles for residential panels.
explanations.D: 60 circuits exceeds current code limits for residential panels.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: When installing a panelboard, what clearance is required in front of the panel?

options.B: 0.75 meter
options.C: 1 meter minimum width and depth with adequate height clearance

explanations.A: 0.5 meter is insufficient for safe working space.
explanations.B: 0.75 meter does not meet minimum code requirements.
explanations.C: CEC requires minimum 1 meter working space in front of panels (width and depth) with adequate height clearance (typically 2 meters) for safe access and maintenance.
explanations.D: Adequate working space is mandatory for safety and code compliance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What type of panel must be used in wet or damp locations?

options.B: NEMA rated weatherproof or watertight panel suitable for the environment
options.D: Panels cannot be installed in wet locations

explanations.A: Standard indoor panels are not rated for wet or damp environments.
explanations.B: Wet or damp locations require NEMA-rated panels (NEMA 3R for weather-resistant, NEMA 4/4X for watertight) specifically designed to prevent water intrusion.
explanations.C: Standard covers do not provide adequate protection; purpose-built weatherproof enclosures are required.
explanations.D: Panels can be installed in wet locations if properly rated for the environment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: How should neutral and ground bars be configured in a main service panel?

options.B: Bonded together at the main service panel only using a main bonding jumper

explanations.A: At the main service, neutral and ground must be bonded, not isolated.
explanations.B: The main service panel is the only point where neutral and grounding are bonded together using a main bonding jumper, creating the system grounded conductor connection.
explanations.C: Resistors are not used in neutral-ground bonding; a solid connection is required.
explanations.D: Ground bars are essential for equipment grounding conductor connections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What size feeder conductors are required for a 100A subpanel located 30 meters from the main panel?

options.A: Same size as would be used at the panel location without considering voltage drop
options.B: Conductors must be sized for 100A ampacity and checked for voltage drop; upsize if needed to limit drop to 3%

explanations.A: Distance creates voltage drop that must be considered in conductor sizing.
explanations.B: Feeder conductors must have adequate ampacity for the load (100A) and be sized to limit voltage drop to 3% or less, which may require larger conductors for longer distances.
explanations.C: Conductor size must be adequate for current and voltage drop, not arbitrary.
explanations.D: Distance directly affects voltage drop and is critical in conductor sizing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is a loadcenter?

options.B: A type of panelboard commonly used in residential applications that combines main overcurrent protection with branch circuit breakers

explanations.A: Loadcenters are distribution panels, not motor controllers.
explanations.B: A loadcenter is a residential-type panelboard that typically includes the main breaker and branch circuit breakers in one enclosure, designed for residential and light commercial use.
explanations.C: Loadcenters distribute power but do not transform voltage.
explanations.D: Metering is separate from loadcenter function.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What labeling is required on distribution panels?

options.B: Circuit directory identifying each circuit's load and location

explanations.A: Circuit identification is mandatory for safe operation and maintenance.
explanations.B: CEC requires a circuit directory at all panelboards clearly identifying each circuit breaker's purpose and the areas or equipment served for safety and operational purposes.
explanations.C: While voltage rating is important, circuit identification is also required.
explanations.D: Manufacturer information is on the equipment label but circuit directories are separately required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the primary cause of overheating in panelboards?

options.B: Loose connections, overloaded circuits, or insufficient wire bending space

explanations.A: Proper ventilation prevents overheating; it is not a cause.
explanations.B: Overheating results from loose connections creating high resistance, circuits loaded beyond capacity, or conductors bent too tightly causing insulation compression and increased resistance.
explanations.C: Panel size does not cause overheating; undersized panels or overcrowding do.
explanations.D: Correct breaker sizing prevents overheating; it is not a cause.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What tools are essential for servicing panelboards?

options.B: Voltage testers, screwdrivers, torque tools, infrared thermometer, and insulated tools

explanations.A: Hammers and pliers are insufficient for proper electrical panel service.
explanations.B: Panel servicing requires voltage testers for safety verification, proper screwdrivers and torque tools for connections, thermal imaging or IR thermometer for hot spot detection, and insulated tools for safety.
explanations.C: Specialized tools are essential for safe and effective panel service.
explanations.D: Manual hand tools and test equipment are essential; power tools have limited panel servicing applications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: How should bus bar connections be inspected during panel service?

options.A: Visual inspection only from outside the panel
options.B: After de-energization, inspect for tight connections, discoloration, pitting, and proper breaker seating on bus bars
options.D: Only check if there's a complete power failure

explanations.A: External visual inspection cannot assess bus bar condition; internal inspection after de-energization is required.
explanations.B: Bus bar inspection includes verifying tight connections, checking for heat-induced discoloration or damage, looking for pitting or corrosion, and ensuring breakers properly seat on bus stabs.
explanations.C: Regular bus bar inspection is essential for preventing failures and fires.
explanations.D: Proactive inspection prevents failures; waiting for complete failure is unsafe and costly.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the purpose of infrared thermal scanning of panels?

options.B: To detect hot spots indicating loose connections, overloaded circuits, or failing components before catastrophic failure

explanations.A: Thermal imaging is diagnostic, not cosmetic.
explanations.B: Infrared thermal imaging detects abnormal heat patterns in panels, identifying loose connections, overloaded conductors, or failing components before they cause fires or equipment damage.
explanations.C: Thermal imaging detects heat, not voltage; multimeters measure voltage.
explanations.D: Age determination requires manufacturing date inspection, not thermal imaging.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: When should panel bus bars be replaced?

options.B: When showing signs of severe overheating, pitting, corrosion, or physical damage compromising electrical integrity
options.D: Only when the building is demolished

explanations.A: Annual replacement is unnecessary if bus bars are in good condition.
explanations.B: Bus bars require replacement when damaged by overheating (discoloration, melting), corrosion, pitting that reduces contact area, or physical damage that compromises current-carrying capability.
explanations.C: Bus bars can degrade and fail over time, especially if subjected to fault currents or environmental factors.
explanations.D: Failed or damaged bus bars must be replaced immediately to maintain safety.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What maintenance should be performed on panel neutral and ground bars?

options.A: Tighten all terminal screws, inspect for corrosion, verify proper bonding configuration, and ensure adequate torque
options.B: No maintenance needed

explanations.A: Neutral and ground bar maintenance includes checking and tightening terminals, inspecting for corrosion or damage, verifying proper bonding (bonded at main service, isolated at subpanels), and ensuring proper torque.
explanations.B: Regular maintenance is essential to ensure proper grounding and neutral function.
explanations.C: Painting provides no functional benefit and may interfere with connections.
explanations.D: Water cleaning is inappropriate and dangerous for electrical equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: How should you respond to finding a burnt breaker during panel service?

options.A: Ignore it if the circuit still works
options.B: Replace the breaker and investigate the cause (overload, short circuit, or loose connection)
options.C: Just clean off the burn marks
options.D: Move the circuit to a different breaker without investigation

explanations.A: Burnt breakers indicate serious problems that must be addressed.
explanations.B: Burnt breakers must be replaced, and the cause must be identified and correctedwhether overloaded circuit, fault condition, or loose connectionto prevent recurrence.
explanations.C: Cleaning does not address the damage or underlying problem; replacement is required.
explanations.D: Moving circuits without investigating why the breaker burned does not address the root cause.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What documentation should be maintained for panel service work?

options.B: Service records including date, work performed, findings, corrections made, and test results
options.D: Documentation is only required for new installations

explanations.A: Documentation is essential for tracking panel condition and service history.
explanations.B: Comprehensive service records should include date, description of work, problems found, corrective actions, test results, and technician identification for future reference and warranty purposes.
explanations.C: Photographs supplement but don't replace written service documentation.
explanations.D: Service work documentation is as important as new installation documentation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the purpose of a main lug panel versus a main breaker panel?

options.B: Main lug panels have no main disconnect and are fed from upstream overcurrent protection; main breaker panels include integrated main disconnects
options.C: Main lug panels are only for temporary use
options.D: Main breaker panels cannot be used as service entrance

explanations.A: Significant differences exist between main lug and main breaker panels.
explanations.B: Main lug panels have lugs for feeder connections but no integrated main breaker, relying on upstream protection; main breaker panels include the main overcurrent device and can serve as service entrance equipment.
explanations.C: Main lug panels are for permanent installations as subpanels, not temporary use.
explanations.D: Main breaker panels are commonly used as service entrance equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power distribution equipment
questions.question: What is the significance of a panel's SCCR (Short Circuit Current Rating)?

options.A: It indicates the panel's continuous current capacity
options.B: It indicates the maximum fault current the panel can safely withstand without catastrophic failure
options.C: It measures the panel's voltage rating

explanations.A: Continuous capacity is indicated by main breaker or bus rating, not SCCR.
explanations.B: SCCR indicates the maximum available fault current the panel assembly (bus bars, enclosure, breakers) can safely handle during a short circuit without mechanical failure or fire.
explanations.C: Voltage rating is separate from short circuit current rating.
explanations.D: SCCR is critical for ensuring panels can safely handle available fault current at their installation location.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power conditioning, uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
questions.subtask: B-10.01 Installs uninterruptible power supply (UPS) and power conditioning equipment
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an uninterruptible power supply (UPS)?

options.B: To provide emergency backup power during utility power failures and condition power quality
options.D: To replace the main electrical service

explanations.A: UPS systems increase costs; they do not reduce electricity consumption.
explanations.B: UPS systems provide seamless backup power during outages using batteries, and many models also condition power by filtering surges, sags, and harmonics to protect sensitive equipment.
explanations.C: UPS systems maintain voltage but do not increase it beyond normal levels.
explanations.D: UPS systems provide temporary backup, not permanent power supply replacement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power conditioning, uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
questions.subtask: B-10.01 Installs uninterruptible power supply (UPS) and power conditioning equipment
questions.question: What is the difference between an online (double-conversion) UPS and an offline (standby) UPS?

options.B: Online UPS continuously powers the load through the inverter providing seamless protection; offline UPS switches to battery only during outages with brief transfer time

explanations.A: Significant operational differences exist between online and offline UPS topologies.
explanations.B: Online UPS continuously converts AC to DC and back to AC, providing constant power conditioning and zero transfer time; offline UPS normally passes utility power and switches to battery during outages with 2-10ms transfer time.
explanations.C: Online UPS systems are typically more expensive due to continuous conversion and superior protection.
explanations.D: Online UPS provides the best power conditioning by continuously regenerating clean power.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power conditioning, uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
questions.subtask: B-10.01 Installs uninterruptible power supply (UPS) and power conditioning equipment
questions.question: What size UPS is required for a load drawing 800 watts with a power factor of 0.8?

options.B: 640 VA

explanations.A: 800 VA does not account for power factor; it would be inadequate.
explanations.B: 640 VA is the real power but not the VA rating needed.
explanations.C: VA = Watts / Power Factor = 800W / 0.8 = 1000 VA. UPS must be sized for apparent power (VA) not just real power (watts).
explanations.D: 1600 VA is oversized and unnecessarily expensive for this load.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power conditioning, uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
questions.subtask: B-10.01 Installs uninterruptible power supply (UPS) and power conditioning equipment
questions.question: What type of wiring is required from the UPS to critical loads?

options.A: Standard branch circuit wiring; no special requirements
options.B: Dedicated circuits clearly identified as UPS-powered to prevent confusion with utility-powered circuits
options.C: Any available circuit can be used

explanations.A: While standard wiring methods apply, identification is critical.
explanations.B: UPS output circuits must be dedicated to UPS-powered loads and clearly identified to prevent accidental connection of non-critical loads and to ensure proper load management.
explanations.C: Random circuit usage defeats the purpose of selective backup power.
explanations.D: Extension cords are not acceptable for permanent UPS installations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, services and maintains power conditioning, uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
